titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: A cold gusty day, in which winter & spring seemed to contend on even terms. I spent the morning in revising the proof of "
about the Winchester memorial. After lunch I motored to Bromyard, and confirmed 65 candidates in the parish church. Of these the majority were males. During my absence the
took their departure. On my return I had an interview with a queer man who works at the munition factory, & was formerly a schoolmaster.
Then I wrote a letter to the "Times" on the "Life and Liberty" subject, taking occasion by a letter in Today's issue from the Bristol Congregationalist
, and, on the whole, answering effectively. After dinner I read "Barnaby Rudge" to my ladies.
told me that it was not unusual in the country districts for the local publican to arrange a dance on the occasion of the Confirmation, & to advertise the price of admission,
"Confirmed girls in their Confirmation dress admitted free"
This seems a grossly incongruous dénouement to the ceremony in the Church. Probably it doesn't seem so grotesquely inappropriate to the class which uses public houses.
